title: Sued by a credit card company for 2 cards. What are my options?
question: I had two credit cards from one provider. Because of financial issues I had and two many bills I decided not to pay anymore. Now they sued me and I just received the papers from a server. What to do next? I was thinking to file for reorganization chapter 13 as I do have many unpaid and unaffordable bills. 4 years ago I had filed for chapt 7. Thank you for your help
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,General Practice
answers: Chapter 13 is a powerful tool for someone in your position. After a substantial consultation with a local Bankruptcy attorney who has excellent reviews on AVVO and YELP, you will probably find that it can be a relatively painless process that will not only protect you, but allow you to breathe. Good choice!

Sounds like Chapter 13 may be a good option. You may qualify for a low percentage plan, whereby creditors will be required to accept a small payback based on your income and expenses and Means Test. Consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your area who handles a lot of Chapter 13 cases.

Filing Bankruptcy, a Chapter 13 appears to be a very good option for you. You should end up with an affordable payment plan for the cost of attorney, trustee and court fees. Your credit report will show the debts discharged in bankruptcy and you can start fresh to rebuild your credit. Sometimes the discipline of a chapter 13 helps figure a budget system that works for you so that you can accomplish other financial goals after your chapter 13, such as saving.
Take advantage of free consulations to find the attorney you feel most comfortable with. This isn't a DIY project.

I agree that consideration of Chapter 13 is spot on. It's nice to gt a question from someone like you who has already done their homework. You obviously have determined that your Ch 7 case disqualifies you from another ch 7 discharge at this time, but that you may be eligible for a Ch 13 discharge.

Most BK lawyers will give you a free consultation so you can find out if it's going to be good for you. I suggest that you not hesitate to consult several or more lawyers. You will find there are big differences between lawyers in what they know, what they charge, and their level of friendliness.

Wondering how you will pay for a bankruptcy when you are broke? Here is an avvo guide that may help you find the way to pay for your bankruptcy case. https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/bankruptcy-fees-are-affordable

Your thinking is correct. If you already filed chapter 7 you cannot file again for eight years. You are entitled to a discharge 4 years later. So, you can file chapter 13 and based on your disposable income and assets, you may be able to pay a small payment per month ($100 or so) and then have all of your remaining debt discharged after 3-5 years. All interest stops accruing as well. Speak with a bankruptcy attorney to discuss this option.
